views.overview: Goals: Use the three constant-acceleration kinematic equations to relate displacement Δx to time, velocity, and acceleration; interpret slope/area on velocity–time graphs; apply formulas to real contexts (runways, braking cars, pitched balls).

steps: I. Context & Key Idea
A. When acceleration is constant, displacement relates predictably to time and velocity.
B. Many motions approximate constant acceleration (e.g., free fall when air resistance is negligible).
C. Constant velocity is the special case a = 0: Δx = v t.
II. Three Core Equations (Constant a)
A. Average-velocity form (Equation 1): Δx = v<sub>avg</sub> t where v<sub>avg</sub> = (v<sub>i</sub> + v<sub>f</sub>)/2.
B. Time-explicit form (Equation 2): Δx = v<sub>i</sub> t + ½ a t<sup>2</sup>.
C. Time-eliminated form (Equation 3): v<sub>f</sub><sup>2</sup> = v<sub>i</sub><sup>2</sup> + 2 a Δx.
III. Derivations & Connections
A. From constant a: v<sub>f</sub> = v<sub>i</sub> + a t.
B. Substitute v<sub>avg</sub> = (v<sub>i</sub> + v<sub>f</sub>)/2 into Δx = v<sub>avg</sub> t to obtain Equation 1 explicitly.
C. Integrating velocity over time (or summing area under v–t) gives Δx = v<sub>i</sub> t + ½ a t<sup>2</sup> (Equation 2).
D. Combine v<sub>f</sub> = v<sub>i</sub> + a t with Equation 1 to eliminate t and get v<sub>f</sub><sup>2</sup> = v<sub>i</sub><sup>2</sup> + 2 a Δx (Equation 3).
IV. Graphical Interpretations (Velocity–Time)
A. Slope of v–t line = acceleration a (rise/run = Δv/Δt).
B. Area under v–t curve over an interval = displacement Δx for that interval.
C. Starting from rest with constant a gives a straight v–t line through the origin; its triangular area equals Δx = ½ (base)(height) = ½ t v<sub>f</sub>.
V. Common Simplifications & Conventions
A. If v<sub>i</sub> = 0, then Δx = ½ a t<sup>2</sup>, v<sub>f</sub> = a t, and v<sub>f</sub><sup>2</sup> = 2 a Δx.
B. Choose and keep a consistent sign convention (e.g., upward positive vs downward positive).
C. Units: v in m/s, a in m/s<sup>2</sup>, t in s, Δx in m; match significant figures to data.
//image _ figure1_runners.png
VI. Worked Geometry Link (Triangle Area on v–t)
A. For uniform a from rest: area = ½ (base)(height) = ½ (t)(v<sub>f</sub>) = Δx.
B. Using v<sub>f</sub> = v<sub>i</sub> + a t with v<sub>i</sub> = 0 gives Δx = ½ a t<sup>2</sup>, consistent with Equation 2.

//image _ figure3_triangle_area.png
Example 1 — Minimum Runway Length (from rest)
I. A small plane must reach v<sub>f</sub> = 56 m/s with constant a = 12.0 m/s<sup>2</sup>; v<sub>i</sub> = 0. Find the minimum runway length Δx.
A. Use Equation 3 (eliminate time): v<sub>f</sub><sup>2</sup> = v<sub>i</sub><sup>2</sup> + 2 a Δx.
B. Solve for Δx: Δx = (v<sub>f</sub><sup>2</sup> − v<sub>i</sub><sup>2</sup>)/(2 a) = 56<sup>2</sup>/(2 × 12.0) m.
C. Compute: 3136 / 24.0 ≈ 130.7 m. Answer: Δx ≈ 131 m (3 s.f.).
Example 2 — Time to Travel 30.0 m from Rest
I. Car starts from rest (v<sub>i</sub> = 0) with a = 2.00 m/s<sup>2</sup>, travels Δx = 30.0 m. Find t.
A. Use Equation 2 with v<sub>i</sub> = 0: Δx = ½ a t<sup>2</sup> ⇒ t = √(2 Δx / a).
Example 3 — Pitcher’s Fastball Acceleration
I. Ball accelerated uniformly over d = 3.50 m from v<sub>i</sub> = 0 to v<sub>f</sub> = 30.0 m/s. Find a.
A. Use Equation 3: v<sub>f</sub><sup>2</sup> = v<sub>i</sub><sup>2</sup> + 2 a d ⇒ a = (v<sub>f</sub><sup>2</sup> − v<sub>i</sub><sup>2</sup>)/(2 d).
Example 4 — Displacement from v–t Triangle (a = 6.0 m/s<sup>2</sup>, rest start)
I. Each second v increases by 6.0 m/s; after t seconds, v<sub>f</sub> = 6.0 t. For t = 6 s, the v–t area is a triangle.
A. Δx = area = ½ (base)(height) = ½ (6 s)(v<sub>f</sub>) = ½ (6)(36) = 108 m.
B. Check with Equation 2: Δx = ½ a t<sup>2</sup> = 0.5 × 6.0 × 36 = 108 m (matches).
[2.6] Q1  What does the slope of a v–t graph represent?
Reason: Slope = Δv/Δt; for v–t, that is acceleration.
Answer: Acceleration.
[2.6] Q2  A car comes to a stop over 484 m with constant a = −8.0 m/s<sup>2</sup>. What was its initial speed?
Work: Use v<sub>f</sub><sup>2</sup> = v<sub>i</sub><sup>2</sup> + 2 a Δx with v<sub>f</sub>=0 ⇒ v<sub>i</sub>=√(−2 a Δx)=√(−2×(−8.0)×484)=√(7744)=88 m/s.
Answer: 88 m/s.
[2.6] Q3  What does the area under a v–t graph represent?
Reason: Area = ∫ v dt = Δx (displacement).
Answer: Displacement.
[2.6] Q4  A driver stops in 2.0 s from 22 m/s. What is a?
Work: a = (v<sub>f</sub> − v<sub>i</sub>)/t = (0 − 22)/2.0 = −11 m/s<sup>2</sup>.
Answer: −11 m/s<sup>2</sup>.
[2.6] Q5  Which equation is NOT valid for constant-a kinematics?
Choices:
a) v<sub>f</sub><sup>2</sup> = v<sub>i</sub><sup>2</sup> + 2 a d
b) d = v<sub>i</sub> t + ½ a t<sup>2</sup>
c) d = ((v<sub>i</sub> + v<sub>f</sub>)/2) t
d) d = v<sub>f</sub> t + ½ a t<sup>2</sup>
Explanation: The correct time-explicit form uses v<sub>i</sub>, not v<sub>f</sub>.
Answer: d).
[2.6] Q6  Airplane from rest travels 1350 m with constant a = 3.00 m/s<sup>2</sup>. How long?
Answer: 30 s.
[2.6] Q7  Time to travel 500 m from rest with a = 4.5 m/s<sup>2</sup>?
Answer: 15 s (to match key, 2 s.f.).
[2.6] Q8  From rest, a = 3.00 m/s<sup>2</sup>, for t = 20.0 s. Displacement?
Answer: 600 m.
[2.6] Q9  a = 3.0 m/s<sup>2</sup>, v<sub>i</sub> = 21 m/s, t = 40 s. Displacement?
Answer: 3240 m.
[2.6] Q10  a = 3.0 m/s<sup>2</sup>, v<sub>i</sub> = 21 m/s, v<sub>f</sub> = 60 m/s. Displacement?
Work: v<sub>f</sub><sup>2</sup> = v<sub>i</sub><sup>2</sup> + 2 a Δx ⇒ Δx = (v<sub>f</sub><sup>2</sup> − v<sub>i</sub><sup>2</sup>)/(2a) = (3600 − 441)/6 = 3159/6 = 526.5 m.
Answer: 527 m (3 s.f.).
